final_answer.precision_note: Result given to three significant figures, matching the precision of current, time and constants.

method: The charge passed during electrolysis was calculated using Q = I 	imes t, with current I = 1.50 A (L51) and time t = 30.0 min = 1800 s, giving Q = 2700 C. The number of moles of electrons was obtained from n(e-) = Q / F, using the Faraday constant F = 96,500 C mol-1 (L19), yielding n(e-) = 2.7985 	imes 10^-2 mol. Each copper atom requires two electrons (half‑reaction Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu, L52), so moles of Cu deposited are n(Cu) = n(e-) / 2 = 1.3993 	imes 10^-2 mol. Multiplying by the molar mass of copper, Mr(Cu) = 63.55 g mol-1 (L25), gives the mass of copper deposited: m = 0.888 g. All intermediate results were retained to three‑significant‑figure precision as dictated by the source data.
checks: Charge (Q) computed correctly from current and time.
Moles of electrons calculated using the correct Faraday constant.
Stoichiometric conversion from electrons to Cu applied correctly.
Final mass of Cu derived using the correct molar mass.
